meeting_annotations.speaker: Elaine Hsiao, UCLA
meeting_annotations.transcript: really complex organoid multi-organ systems, but also um, you know, utility of these reductionist systems too. I think was part of that too.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Elaine Hsiao, UCLA
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think there is also maybe another point um that could be a big take home point is the importance of cross referencing with in vivo data so that we kind of ensure that it's always rooted in something um hopefully physiologically relevant and um I think Sarkis I think was alluding to an iterative approach like kind of always going back and forth between your um reductionist model and in vivo data. So that that's one thing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sarkis Mazmanian, Caltech
meeting_annotations.transcript: also think the does it make sense to people to so if if one were to build out an in vitro system again I personally think the value one of the the value drivers is that you can humanize those in vitro systems, right? So instead of maybe picking one or the other, um you know, one one additional approach would be to build out both a mouse and human system um just to see the value of the two species and and how how similar or different they are.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen, University of Oregon

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen, University of Oregon
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, they're only relevant to the mouse if you're using the mouse as a model for something else, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sarkis Mazmanian, Caltech

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faronak Fattahi, UCSF

So basically when we were thinking about the ideal in vitro system, do we want it to be then screenable or are we going to take that in vitro model and sort through thousands of metabolites and products and figure out what's um stimulating certain changes or we already have let's say 50 different things that we know are doing something potentially, we just want to take the in vitro model and test those 50.
